conclusion: Moving the light to the back-right means the illumination now arrives from behind the objects and from the right-hand side.
Shadows therefore have to fall in the opposite direction: forward (toward the viewer/front of the table) and toward the left.
Because the light is now farther from 'straight-overhead', its rays strike the objects at a shallower angle.
Shallower angles always lengthen shadows, so every shadow will grow longer/larger.
The shadow of the apple (A) is currently circular/oval and positioned to the right of the apple.
The shadow of the apple (A) will shift forward-left of the apple.
The shadow of the apple (A) will become noticeably larger and more elongated (still roughly circular/oval).
The shadow of the white cloth (B) is currently rectangular and positioned to the right of the cloth.
The shadow of the white cloth (B) will move forward-left of the cloth.
The shadow of the white cloth (B) will enlarge, forming a longer, somewhat squashed rectangle.
The shadow of the glass (C) is currently circular and positioned to the right of the glass.
The shadow of the glass (C) will translate forward-left of the glass.
The shadow of the glass (C) will lengthen; the dark 'ring' at the base stretches into an oval-plus-stem shape.
The shadow of the chicken drumstick (D) is currently positioned to the right of the drumstick.
The shadow of the chicken drumstick (D) will slide forward-left of the drumstick.
The shadow of the chicken drumstick (D) will lengthen; the bone-end and meat-end features appear slightly more separated in the longer shadow.

After the light is relocated to the back right, every shadow (A, B, C, D) moves to the front-left of its object and becomes longer/larger than before, with their individual silhouettes retaining their distinctive shapes but in a stretched form.
